{{short description|History book by Hugh Thomas}} {{Infobox book | name = The Spanish Civil War | author = [[Hugh Thomas, Baron Thomas of Swynnerton|Hugh Thomas]] | country = | language = English | subject = [[Spanish Civil War]] | published = 1961 | media_type = Print | pages = xx, 1115 [3rd, revised ed.] | isbn =0060142782 | congress= }}
'''''The Spanish Civil War''''' is a book by British historian [[Hugh Thomas, Baron Thomas of Swynnerton|Hugh Thomas]], first published in London by [[Eyre & Spottiswoode]] (xxix, 720 pages, illustrated with photos and maps).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://opac.navalmarinearchive.com/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=28005|title= ''The Spanish Civil War'', First Edition.|website= Naval Marine Archive| access-date= 29 August 2019}}</ref> It won the [[Somerset Maugham Prize]] in 1962.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/10/books/hugh-thomas-dead-british-historian-novelist.html|title= Hugh Thomas, Prodigious Author of Spanish History, Dies at 85|last= Cowell|first= Alan |date= May 10, 2017|website= The New York Times |publisher= |access-date= 9 August 2018|quote=}} </ref> A second revised edition was published by [[Penguin Books]] in 1965.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://opac.navalmarinearchive.com/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=42456|title= ''The Spanish Civil War'', revised edition.|website= Naval Marine Archive| access-date= 29 August 2019}}</ref> A third, revised and enlarged edition was published in 1977 by [[Harper & Row]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://opac.navalmarinearchive.com/cgi-bin/koha/opac-detail.pl?biblionumber=18493|title= ''The Spanish Civil War'', revised and enlarged edition.|website= Naval Marine Archive |ISBN=0060142782 |access-date= 29 August 2019}}</ref> which was printed again in 2001 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/hugh-thomas-10/the-spanish-civil-war-3/ |title= Kirkus Review |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= Kirkus |publisher= 19 August 2019 |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> Thomas said that the excellent reviews the book got on its release were a determining factor in his own life and career.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/05/08/inenglish/1494240641_585596.html |title= Obituary: Hugh Thomas, author of seminal book on the Spanish Civil War|last=Guimón |first= Pablo|date= 8 May 2017 |newspaper= El País |publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019 |quote=}}</ref>
The book has been translated in various languages, among them Greek, French and Spanish.
==Reception==
Upon its release in 1961, John Murray called it "an exhaustive study, ably and conscientiously documented".<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Murray |first1= John|date= Winter 1961 |title= Reviewed Works: The Spanish Civil War by Hugh Thomas; The Grand Camouflage by Burnett Bolloten |url= |journal=An Irish Quarterly Review |volume= 50|issue= 200 |pages= 445–447 here 445 |jstor=30103647 }}</ref> In 1963, Robert G. Colodny wrote a similarly positive review, praising in particular the vast amount of research material examined.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Golodny |first1= Robert G.|date= Winter 1963 |title= The Spanish Civil War by Hugh Thomas|url= |journal=Science & Society |volume=27 |issue= 1|pages=77–80 here 77 |jstor=40400911 }}</ref>
Shortly after the death of Thomas, [[Pablo Guimón]] called it "a seminal book on the [[Spanish Civil War]]", "a highly influential work during the country's [[Spanish transition to democracy|transition to democracy]]" and "a classic reference in the existing literature about the 1936-1939 period in Spanish history".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/05/08/inenglish/1494240641_585596.html |title= Obituary: Hugh Thomas, author of seminal book on the Spanish Civil War|last=Guimón |first= Pablo|date= 8 May 2017 |newspaper= El País |publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019 |quote=}}</ref> [[Paul Preston]] claimed that "it marked the first attempt at an objective general view" of the Civil War.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/may/09/lord-thomas-of-swynnerton-obituary|title=Lord Thomas of Swynnerton obituary |last=Preston |first= Paul|date= |website= The Guardian|publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019|quote=}}</ref>
[[Richard Baxell]] wrote that "it is by no means faultless; there are many errors of fact and judgement and Thomas has rightly been accused of occasionally valuing narrative style above factual accuracy." Baxell is also critical of the romanticized depiction of International Brigaders in the first edition.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.richardbaxell.info/hugh-thomas/ |title= Hugh Thomas and The Spanish Civil War|last=Baxell |first=Richard |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019|quote=}}</ref>
==Spanish translation==
The book was forbidden in [[Francoist Spain]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/2001/11/22/cultura/1006383601_850215.html |title= Hugh Thomas afirma que los orígenes de la guerra civil son difíciles de entender|last= Samaniego |first= Fernando |date= 22 November 2001 |newspaper= El País |access-date= 19 August 2019 |quote=}}</ref> The translation and publication of the book was undertaken by Ruedo Ibérico, a publishing house in Paris, founded by Spanish political refugees. It was targeted by Francoist authorities, and was the target of a terrorist attack by a pro-Franco group.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Sanz Gallego|first1= Guillermo|date= 2016-08-30|title= La traducción como manipulación historiográfica en el exilio: análisis paratextual e intertextual de la Guerra Civil Española de Hugh Thomas |url=http://arbor.revistas.csic.es/index.php/arbor/article/view/2144/2855 |journal= Pensamiento y Cultura|volume=192-780 |issue= 780|pages=340 |doi= |access-date= 19 August 2018 }}</ref> Copies were smuggled across the border with France, and Spaniards caught in possession of the book sometimes went to prison. For example a [[Valencia]]n, Octavio Jordá, was caught at the French border having a pair of suitcases packed with many copies of the book. Jordá was later found guilty of "illegal propaganda" and "spreading communism", and sentenced to two years' imprisonment. It wasn't until after [[Francisco Franco]]’s death in 1975 that the book could be freely distributed in Spain.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/hugh-thomas-historian-whose-spanish-civil-war-was-smuggled-across-borders-dies-at-85/2017/05/13/b67f67a2-3722-11e7-b373-418f6849a004_story.html?noredirect=on |title=Hugh Thomas, historian whose 'Spanish Civil War' was smuggled across borders, dies at 85 |last= Schudel|first=Matt |date= 13 May 2017 |website= The Washington Post |publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019|quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/may/09/lord-thomas-of-swynnerton-obituary|title=Lord Thomas of Swynnerton obituary |last=Preston |first= Paul|date= |website= The Guardian|publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019|quote=}} It was accepted for publication in 1976. </ref>
In response to Thomas's book, Franco's then minister of information, [[Manuel Fraga]], set up an official centre for civil war studies to promote the regime's official historiography. So successful was the book that even [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] was regularly asked to comment on statements in it.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/may/09/lord-thomas-of-swynnerton-obituary|title=Lord Thomas of Swynnerton obituary |last=Preston |first= Paul|date= |website= The Guardian|publisher= |access-date= 19 August 2019|quote=}}</ref>
In 2016, Spanish historian Guillermo Sanz Gallego argued that the Spanish translator, José Martinez, manipulated his translation to follow an ideological pattern that favoured the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican]] side. Moreover, the translation used less objective language than the original text when narrating events such as the assassinations of [[José Calvo Sotelo]] and [[Federico García Lorca]]. In the case of the [[Paracuellos massacres]], the number of the deaths, several thousand in the original, was reduced to "approximately a thousand" (millar aproximado).<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Sanz Gallego|first1= Guillermo|date= 2016-08-30|title= La traducción como manipulación historiográfica en el exilio: análisis paratextual e intertextual de la Guerra Civil Española de Hugh Thomas |url=http://arbor.revistas.csic.es/index.php/arbor/article/view/2144/2855 |journal= Pensamiento y Cultura|volume=192-780 |issue= 780|pages=340 |doi= |access-date= 19 August 2018 }}</ref> Sanz Gallego's claims attracted attention from the media.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.elmundo.es/cultura/literatura/2017/06/15/59414b34e2704e51488b45da.html |title=Ruedo Ibérico manipuló 'La Guerra Civil española' de Hugh Thomas en beneficio de la II República |last= Alemany|first= Luis |date= 15 June 2017|website= |publisher= El Mundo |access-date= 19 August 2019 |quote=La Guerra Civil española, del recién fallecido Hugh Thomas, no era como los españoles la leyeron. Pequeños flecos manipulados en la traducción por José Martínez, el editor de Ruedo Ibérico, enfatizaron algunos hechos y atenuaron otros con el fin de exponer un relato más propicio para los defensores de la II República.}}</ref>
